stats.label: Average time a recruiter spends reviewing each resume
Resumes are filtered out by Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) before reaching a human
The ideal resume length preferred by most employers

sections.title: Contact Information
sections.description: Your resume should begin with clear, professional contact details so employers can easily reach you.
tips: Always include your full name, phone number, and a professional email address
Add links to LinkedIn or an online portfolio if available
Avoid using casual or outdated email addresses (e.g., coolguy123@gmail.com)
Listing your city and state is enough — no need for a full street address

sections.title: Professional Summary
sections.description: A short introduction that highlights your career strengths and makes you stand out at first glance.
tips: Keep it to 2–3 sentences that summarize your experience and skills
Tailor the summary to each job you apply for
Use important keywords from the job description to pass ATS filters
Focus on how you can benefit the company, not just your career goals
sections.example: Dynamic marketing professional with 5+ years of experience in digital strategy and brand growth. Skilled in driving engagement, increasing revenue, and leading cross-functional teams to deliver measurable results.

sections.title: Work Experience
sections.description: Showcase your career history with a focus on measurable achievements.
tips: List positions in reverse chronological order (most recent first)
Use action verbs such as 'Led', 'Developed', 'Achieved', and 'Improved'
Quantify your impact with specific metrics (e.g., 20% sales growth, $1M budget managed)
Highlight accomplishments rather than just listing responsibilities
sections.example:
Marketing Specialist | ABC Company | 2020–2023
• Increased social media engagement by 45% through targeted campaigns
• Managed a $50K annual budget and improved ROI by 25%

sections.title: Education
sections.description: Provide details about your academic background and relevant qualifications.
tips: Include your degree, field of study, university name, and graduation year
Mention GPA only if it is strong (3.5 or higher)
Add honors, scholarships, or notable coursework if relevant
Include certifications, workshops, or online training related to the job
sections.example:
Bachelor of Science in Marketing | University of California | 2020
Honors: Dean’s List, Digital Marketing Excellence Award

sections.title: Skills
sections.description: Highlight your most relevant technical and interpersonal skills.
tips: Separate technical skills (software, tools, programming languages) from soft skills (communication, leadership)
Be honest about proficiency levels (Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced)
Match your skills to the requirements in the job posting
Use clear, industry-standard terminology
sections.example:
Technical: Adobe Creative Suite (Advanced), Google Analytics (Proficient), SQL (Intermediate)
Soft Skills: Team Leadership, Strategic Planning, Communication

commonMistakes: Using an unprofessional or outdated email address (e.g., nicknames, casual handles)
Including unnecessary personal details such as age, marital status, or a photo (unless specifically requested)
Making the resume too long — more than 2 pages for most roles
Using vague or passive wording instead of strong action verbs (e.g., 'responsible for' vs. 'led')
Failing to back up achievements with measurable results (percentages, numbers, revenue impact)
Listing outdated, irrelevant, or basic skills (e.g., 'Microsoft Word' as a skill for professionals)
Using inconsistent formatting, poor alignment, or too many font styles
Spelling, grammar, or punctuation errors that create a negative impression
